reviews.review_text: Very interesting story, especially because the author uses a lot of towns and landmarks from my hometown or close by.

The writing style of this novel is a bit odd, but Banks is consistent with it throughout the book. It's a kind of coming-of-age story for a more modern age and it just works. If you are a fan of literary fiction, I would definitely recommend this book to you.
This is an interesting novel, though it gets a bit repetitious at times.
makes me remember when I was that age, and realize I had a great childhood compared too his...Ps my nick name is BONE!
I absolutely loved this book. It was easy to follow along with and inspirational for a new author.
First read this book in high school and re-read it at 25. It was just as great then as now.
Reminiscent of Catcher in the Rye. A bittersweet coming of age story.
One of my all-time favorite books, I've re-read this one many times. Should be more popular than The Catcher in the Rye (which sucks, imo). Really beautiful writing style.

Read this for a book club or otherwise I wouldn't have read it.  Writing very simple and seemed aimed at shock value.  A coming of age compilation that included disparate stereotypes of a dysfunctional upbringing.  No redeeming adults ultimately.  Has been compared to Tom Sawyer and A Catcher in the Rye which is unfair to those books.  Sorry, just would look for other books for inspiration or understanding of the human dilemma.
I loved every word. I remember just the first chapter and gen years later I finally found the book and it's called rule of the bone. And lives up to that awesome name. It's brutal.

summary:
In the tradition Huckleberry Finn and The Catcherin the Rye, Russell Banks’s quintessential novel of a disaffected homeless youth living on the edge of society “redefines the young modern anti-hero. . . . 

Rule of the Bone has its own culture andlanguage, and Bone is sure to become a beloved character for generations” (SanFrancisco Chronicle). With a compelling, off-beat protagonist evocative of Holden Caulfield and Quentin Coldwater, and a narrative voice that masterfully and naturally captures the nuances of a modern vernacular, Banks’s haunting and powerful novel is an indisputable—and unforgettable—modern classic.
